reference.author: Bela Bollobas
reference.title: Modern Graph Theory
Handbook of Large-Scale Random Networks

comment.text: Description: This handbook describes advances in large scale network studies that have taken place in the past 5 years since the publication of the Handbook of Graphs and Networks in 2003 Bornholdt and Schuster 2003. It covers all aspects of large-scale networks, including mathematical foundations and rigorous results of random graph theory, modeling and computational aspects of large-scale networks, as well as areas in physics, biology, neuroscience, sociology and technical areas. Applications range from microscopic to mesoscopic and macroscopic models. The book is based on the material of the NSF workshop on Large-scale Random Graphs held in Budapest in 2006, at the Alfréd Rényi Institute of Mathematics, organized jointly with the University of Memphis.

reference.title: Social Networks: How Simple Parts Make Complex Systems
reference.publisher: University of Washington Department of Psychology's Allen L. Edwards Psychology Lecture Series

comment.text: Focus on social insects as model research systems for exploring how individual behavior is integrated to yield complex, adaptive behavior at the group (colony) level. Their talks cover recent advances in exploring how the behavior of complex systems results from interactions among simple parts. They also look at how we can use network models to understand a wide range of complex systems that impact our daily lives.

reference.title: Markets, Hierarchies and Networks: The Coordination of Social Life

comment.text: From Amazon.com: Social Sytems have long been considered utilising two theoretical models, that of markets and that of hierarchies... This particular volume also introduced an alternative prospectus, that of the network, which had different features, advantages and disdvantages to the other tow approaches and which was able to be compared and contrasted to them. One interesting aspect to the papers contained therein was the admittance to the debate of more complex portrayals of the differing forms of social organisation... and also the the novel idea that the extreme models presented an inadequate picture of the reality which could involve mixtures of the types of systems outlined... The final article is that of Friedrich Hayek, the Nobel prize winner in Economics who sets out a lucid and precise exposition of a way of looking at the world which had not been presented prior to the final article. His dazzling prose provides the icing on the cake for what is a very valuable collection of articles.

reference.title: CDPM: Finding and Evaluating Community Structure in Social Networks
reference.proceedings: 4th International Conference on Advanced Data Mining and Applications
reference.file: Networks/algorithms/clustering/2008 ADMA CDPM Community Structure in Social Networks.pdf

comment.text: ADMA'2008 paper that presents a hierarchical agglomerative clustering algorithm for social networks called CDPM (Clique Directed Percolation Method). Despite following a well-known clustering strategy, its novelty lies in the definition of a Silhouette Coefficient for graphs.

reference.author: Li Wan
Jianxin Liao
Chun Wang
Xiaomin Xu
reference.title: JCCM: Joint Cluster Communities on Attribute and Relationship Data in Social Networks
reference.proceedings: 5th International Conference on Advanced Data Mining and Applications
reference.file: Networks/algorithms/clustering/2009 ADMA JCCM Joint Cluster Communities.pdf

comment.text: ADMA'2009 paper that describes a two-phase clustering algorithm for identifying communities in social networks. The proposed algorithm is compared with some existing algorithms and its results seem to be promising. Surprisingly, however, the authors compare their algorithm with X-Mean, CPM, and CONGA, but they do not compare it with their own CDPM algorithm

reference.author: Yi Wang
Bin Wu
Xin Pei
reference.title: CommTracker: A Core-Based Algorithm of Tracking Community Evolution
reference.proceedings: 4th International Conference on Advanced Data Mining and Applications
reference.file: Networks/algorithms/clustering/2008 ADMA CommTracker - Tracking Community Evolution.pdf

comment.text: ADMA'2008 paper that illustrates how simple but effective ideas (i.e. identifying core nodes) can lead to elegant algorithms that can be helpful in the solution of practical problems (i.e. tracking the evolution of communities in a social network). The proposed algorithm is useful to detect community splits and mergers. Moreover, the algorithm is parameter-free, something that is always welcome in data mining applications.

reference.title: Discovering Overlapping Groups in Social Media
reference.proceedings: 10th International Conference on Data Mining

comment.text: ICDM'2010 paper that describes a a novel co-clustering framework, which takes advantage of networking information between users and tags in social media, to discover these overlapping communities.
